events.title: Adoption of the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen
events.description: The French National Constituent Assembly adopted the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen, a foundational document of the French Revolution asserting individual and collective rights.
events.significance: It laid the groundwork for modern human rights and influenced constitutional law worldwide.

events.title: Women Gain the Right to Vote in the United States
events.description: The 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was certified, guaranteeing American women the right to vote after decades of activism.
events.significance: Marked a major milestone in the women's suffrage movement, significantly expanding democracy in the United States.

events.title: Poland's Student Protests
events.description: Massive student protests erupted in Poland demanding political reform and freedom of speech, part of broader unrest in Eastern Europe during the Cold War.
events.significance: Highlighted growing opposition to communist regimes and fueled future movements for change in Eastern Europe.

events.title: Barack Obama Accepts Democratic Nomination for U.S. President
events.description: At the Democratic National Convention, Barack Obama officially accepted the nomination to become the first African American major party candidate for President of the United States.
events.significance: A historic moment in U.S. politics symbolizing increased racial equality and inspiring political engagement.
